@kuangye098 ^^

@jiazhai - In a regex subscription mode, the subscribers (consumers) usually don't know which topic to delete. So, they will not be able to unsubscribe. 

Pulsar should provide a mechanism to prevent a topic being re-created by a regex consumer.

@sijie Maybe we can continue with this, and throw an exception if the flush doesn't got through because of [these lines](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/PersistentAcknowledgmentsGroupingTracker.java#L153-L158)? 

This behavior also seems to be present in plenty of other places (not responding to unexpected behavior with exceptions). For example, [these lines](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/PersistentAcknowledgmentsGroupingTracker.java#L136-138) can result in acks not being sent and no exception thrown to let the user know.

@huangdx0726 Thank you very much for your contribution!

@epsteina16 Since we are talking about adding a new public API, I think having a pair of sync and async method is a good practice of adding a new method into a client. because introducing a sync method without an async method is inconsistent with other methods which can confuse the users. 

Currently there is no guarantee on "acknowledge". But we are going to change this behavior for transaction support. We should potentially include that for adding this new method. Otherwise, it is going to be hard to maintain once this API is exposed publicly.

Currently I'm using the following workaround to be able to read the last message of a topic:
Use the pulsar-admin-client to get the last-message-id of a topic (-1 means empty topic), then use pulsar-client Consumer.seek to that id and then the next receive call will get the last message of the topic. This is not an ideal solution as it also relies on the pulsar-admin client.

I'm still seeing this problem with 2.4.0.
I'm deploying bookie as stateful set and just using in container storage for testing.
The error seems to be related to zookeeper info and not related to storage.
rerun cpp tests

I have changed my design and now rely on the pulsar client application to track positions rather than using subscriptions and acknowledgements, so I no longer need this feature for what I'm working on. Still I think this option is useful, as it allows using Pulsar subscriptions to be master of stream progress with at-least-once semantics.
